column2: This one suggestion, if faithfully lived up to from the age of one year to that of two years, would be almost enough.
column3: This one suggestion, if faithfully lived up to from the age of one year to that of two years, would be almost enough.

column2: But there are other things that the mother can do as the mental development of the baby increases with each month of life.
column3: But there are other things that the mother can do as the mental development of the baby increases with each month of life.

column2: She should encourage him to babble and gurgle and murmur, as much as possible, to laugh and crow and make all the various baby noises that will train and develop his voice.
column3: She should encourage him to babble and gurgle and murmur, as much as possible, to laugh and crow and make all the various baby noises that will train and develop his voice.

column2: Encourage noisy, romping, rollicking games as he gets older, that make him shout and call, for they are the natural and best voice exercises.
column3: Encourage noisy, romping, rollicking games as he gets older, that make him shout and call, for they are the natural and best voice exercises.

column2: IV
column3: i v

column2: WHAT ABOUT THE BABY'S SPEECH?
column3: WHAT ABOUT THE BABY'S SPEECH?

column2: The hearing baby babbles because he gets some pleasure from the sounds, and also because he desires to imitate the sounds of speech he hears around him.
column3: The hearing baby babbles because he gets some pleasure from the sounds, and also because he desires to imitate the sounds of speech he hears around him.

column2: _He has his attention called constantly to sound._ The sense of vibration is not as strong nor as instructive as that of sound, but if _the attention_ of the child is early _called_ to it, a watchfulness for vibration _from within himself_ as well as from without, can be aroused, and a sensitiveness developed that would not have come as early, if at all, without special, directive effort on the part of the mother.
column3: underscore He has his attention called constantly to sound.underscore The sense of vibration is not as strong nor as instructive as that of sound, but if underscore the attention underscore of the child is early underscore called underscore to it, a watchfulness for vibration underscore from within himself underscore as well as from without, can be aroused, and a sensitiveness developed that would not have come as early, if at all, without special, directive effort on the part of the mother.

column2: She can lead her little one to oo-oo, and ee-ee, and mamma, and bub-bub, etc., by doing these babblings herself while the baby is in her arms and his tiny hands are wandering over her lips and face and throat. These exercises will gradually bring a recognition on the part of the child of the sensation of vibration that accompanies voice, and they will give facility, coupled with the normal and natural intonations that have been acquired when he was not conscious of any effort, that will prepare him for a better and more fluent speech when the time comes for more exact articulation training.
column3: She can lead her little one to oo oo, and ee ee, and mamma, and bub bub, etc, by doing these babblings herself while the baby is in her arms and his tiny hands are wandering over her lips and face and throat. These exercises will gradually bring a recognition on the part of the child of the sensation of vibration that accompanies voice, and they will give facility, coupled with the normal and natural intonations that have been acquired when he was not conscious of any effort, that will prepare him for a better and more fluent speech when the time comes for more exact articulation training.

column2: But during the first two or three years of the child's life the principal stress should be placed upon his learning to understand what is said to him, without bothering much about his speaking himself.
column3: But during the first two or three years of the child's life the principal stress should be placed upon his learning to understand what is said to him, without bothering much about his speaking himself.

column2: In the case of the hearing child, the understanding of language comes before he can himself utter it.
column3: In the case of the hearing child, the understanding of language comes before he can himself utter it.

column2: This must also be the case with the deaf child, and the period preceding utterance must be longer, by reason of his handicap, than in the case of a child with normal hearing.
column3: This must also be the case with the deaf child, and the period preceding utterance must be longer, by reason of his handicap, than in the case of a child with normal hearing.

column2: V
column3: V

column2: DEVELOPING THE MENTAL FACULTIES
column3: DEVELOPING THE MENTAL FACULTIES

column2: By the time he is two years old he has gained maturity and grasp enough to play many little educational games with his mother and his little brothers and sisters, or playmates.
column3: By the time he is two years old he has gained maturity and grasp enough to play many little educational games with his mother and his little brothers and sisters, or playmates.

column2: These games should be calculated to develop his various faculties, his powers of observation, memory, and concentration.
column3: These games should be calculated to develop his various faculties, his powers of observation, memory, and concentration.

column2: To develop a faculty is really _to train the brain_.
column3: To develop a faculty is really underscore to train the brain underscore.

column2: As a matter of fact, we see and hear and taste and smell and feel with our brains.
column3: As a matter of fact, we see and hear and taste and smell and feel with our brains.

column2: The eye of a two-year-old child is practically as perfect an optical instrument as the eye of a boy of ten, and yet how much more the older boy seems to see.
column3: The eye of a two year old child is practically as perfect an optical instrument as the eye of a boy of ten, and yet how much more the older boy seems to see.

column2: This is because his brain has been trained to _interpret_ the impressions that even the baby eyes received but did not understand.
column3: This is because his brain has been trained to underscore interpret underscore the impressions that even the baby eyes received but did not understand.

column2: Of course, where the instrument is found to be imperfect we can assist it by means of additional lenses, or perhaps by some one of the skillful operations now performed by oculists, and, as the sight is of such increased importance to a deaf child, the greatest care and watchfulness should be given to his eyes.
column3: Of course, where the instrument is found to be imperfect we can assist it by means of additional lenses, or perhaps by some one of the skillful operations now performed by oculists, and, as the sight is of such increased importance to a deaf child, the greatest care and watchfulness should be given to his eyes.

column2: Do not let him sleep, or lie, facing the sun, or any other powerful light, but throughout his life be careful that all his use of eyesight be under conditions of ample and well-directed light.
column3: Do not let him sleep, or lie, facing the sun, or any other powerful light, but throughout his life be careful that all his use of eyesight be under conditions of ample and well directed light.

column2: Supposing that the simple tests referred to heretofore have shown that the eyes, as optical instruments, are sufficiently perfect, our efforts need to be to train the brain to take cognizance of, and to interpret the impressions transmitted to it by the eyes.
column3: Supposing that the simple tests referred to heretofore have shown that the eyes, as optical instruments, are sufficiently perfect, our efforts need to be to train the brain to take cognizance of, and to interpret the impressions transmitted to it by the eyes.

column2: We shall not be able to improve the working of the eye by our efforts, but we can educate the brain.
column3: We shall not be able to improve the working of the eye by our efforts, but we can educate the brain.

column2: Color and form make the earliest appeal to the child's eyes, and we can use them for our educational play.
column3: Color and form make the earliest appeal to the child's eyes, and we can use them for our educational play.

column2: The duplicate set of worsted balls of the seven primal colors can be increased to include easily distinguishable shades.
column3: The duplicate set of worsted balls of the seven primal colors can be increased to include easily distinguishable shades.

column2: The child can be sent on entertaining voyages of discovery around the room with a ball of a certain color to find other objects similar in color in the rugs, books, chairs, dresses, ties, etc.
column3: The child can be sent on entertaining voyages of discovery around the room with a ball of a certain color to find other objects similar in color in the rugs, books, chairs, dresses, ties, etc

column2: A game to develop observation of form can be made by collecting a group of objects of varying shapes in a pile on the floor or a low table; mother picks up some one of the objects, directs the attention of the little one to it, and after he has observed it somewhat she puts it back in the pile and moves all the objects about till they are well mixed up. Ask the little fellow then to pick out the object mother held in her hand a moment before.
column3: A game to develop observation of form can be made by collecting a group of objects of varying shapes in a pile on the floor or a low table; mother picks up some one of the objects, directs the attention of the little one to it, and after he has observed it somewhat she puts it back in the pile and moves all the objects about till they are well mixed up. Ask the little fellow then to pick out the object mother held in her hand a moment before.

column2: When he can do this by sight without difficulty, have him shut his eyes, place an object in his little hands, teach him to feel it over carefully, take it from him, and, while his eyes are still closed, place it once more in the pile.
column3: When he can do this by sight without difficulty, have him shut his eyes, place an object in his little hands, teach him to feel it over carefully, take it from him, and, while his eyes are still closed, place it once more in the pile.

column2: Let him then open his eyes and see if he can indicate the object he had previously held.
column3: Let him then open his eyes and see if he can indicate the object he had previously held.

column2: When he has mastered this, give the game another turn by asking him to find by means of touch alone, while the eyes are still closed, the object that he has been feeling, after it is restored to the pile of other objects. Still another turn can be given by first letting him see the object, without touching it, then having him close his eyes, and by touch alone select it from the pile.
column3: When he has mastered this, give the game another turn by asking him to find by means of touch alone, while the eyes are still closed, the object that he has been feeling, after it is restored to the pile of other objects. Still another turn can be given by first letting him see the object, without touching it, then having him close his eyes, and by touch alone select it from the pile.

column2: A set of wooden forms, such as spheres, cubes, pyramids, cones, cylinders, and similar, but truncated, forms, can be obtained at any school supply store.
column3: A set of wooden forms, such as spheres, cubes, pyramids, cones, cylinders, and similar, but truncated, forms, can be obtained at any school supply store.

column2: To these can be added common household objects such as small frames, vases, napkin rings, spoons, forks, and other similar things, as well as some of the forms included in a complete set of the Montessori material.
column3: To these can be added common household objects such as small frames, vases, napkin rings, spoons, forks, and other similar things, as well as some of the forms included in a complete set of the Montessori material.

column2: The Montessori weighted forms are excellent for training his muscular recognition of difference of weight, and an excellent way is to put various quantities of birdshot into half a dozen exactly similar little rubber balls that can be purchased at any toy store for two cents apiece.
column3: The Montessori weighted forms are excellent for training his muscular recognition of difference of weight, and an excellent way is to put various quantities of birdshot into half a dozen exactly similar little rubber balls that can be purchased at any toy store for two cents apiece.

column2: Then hand the boy one of the weighted balls, and after he has felt its weight put it back with the other similar-appearing balls and see if he can again discover it.
column3: Then hand the boy one of the weighted balls, and after he has felt its weight put it back with the other similar appearing balls and see if he can again discover it.

column2: An outfit for training his tactile sense can be made in any home by collecting duplicate pieces of cloth having different textures; such as velvet, rough woolen tweeds or homespun, silk, satin, cambric, muslin, etc., and pasting one set on cards.
column3: An outfit for training his tactile sense can be made in any home by collecting duplicate pieces of cloth having different textures; such as velvet, rough woolen tweeds or homespun, silk, satin, cambric, muslin, etc, and pasting one set on cards.

column2: Also by stretching on a wooden frame, strings of varying sizes, weaves, and twists, and having a bunch of duplicates from which he can select, by sight and touch alone, the pieces that correspond, each to each, with those on the frame or on the cards.
column3: Also by stretching on a wooden frame, strings of varying sizes, weaves, and twists, and having a bunch of duplicates from which he can select, by sight and touch alone, the pieces that correspond, each to each, with those on the frame or on the cards.

column2: If there is a guitar, or mandolin, or zither, or a piano, available, perhaps, by and by, the mother can teach the child to recognize the difference in the vibratory sensation perceived by his fingers touching the body of the instrument when a low note and a high note are struck alternately.
column3: If there is a guitar, or mandolin, or zither, or a piano, available, perhaps, by and by, the mother can teach the child to recognize the difference in the vibratory sensation perceived by his fingers touching the body of the instrument when a low note and a high note are struck alternately.

column2: She can make a game of this, too, by later having him close his eyes and place his fingers in contact with the instrument and then tell her _approximately_ what string or key she struck.
column3: She can make a game of this, too, by later having him close his eyes and place his fingers in contact with the instrument and then tell her underscore approximately underscore what string or key she struck.

column2: The next step, if she can take it, is to place his little hands upon her chest to feel the lowest notes of her voice, and upon both the chest and the top of her head to feel the highest, and endeavoring to get him to recognize the similarity in vibratory sensation between what he now feels and what he previously felt on the musical instruments.
column3: The next step, if she can take it, is to place his little hands upon her chest to feel the lowest notes of her voice, and upon both the chest and the top of her head to feel the highest, and endeavoring to get him to recognize the similarity in vibratory sensation between what he now feels and what he previously felt on the musical instruments.

column2: The last step in this series of exercises to awaken a recognition of vibratory sensations is to lead him to feel in his own chest and head the vibrations set up by his own voice in shouting and laughing, crying or babbling.
column3: The last step in this series of exercises to awaken a recognition of vibratory sensations is to lead him to feel in his own chest and head the vibrations set up by his own voice in shouting and laughing, crying or babbling.

column2: These hints that are so quickly and easily given, require weeks and months of patient, _happy_ effort to carry out.
column3: These hints that are so quickly and easily given, require weeks and months of patient, underscore happy underscore effort to carry out.

column2: Beware that no one of them is repeated or continued so long at a time as to become a thing dreaded and disliked.
column3: Beware that no one of them is repeated or continued so long at a time as to become a thing dreaded and disliked.

column2: Remember that the attention of a little child is like a constantly flitting butterfly that rests for only a moment or two on anything before dancing away to something else.
column3: Remember that the attention of a little child is like a constantly flitting butterfly that rests for only a moment or two on anything before dancing away to something else.

column2: There are many little games with kindergarten materials that can be used to develop the powers of attention, observation, imitation, and obedience.
column3: There are many little games with kindergarten materials that can be used to develop the powers of attention, observation, imitation, and obedience.

column2: The laying in simple designs, by watchful imitation of the mother, of colored sticks, colored squares, etc.; the building with colored blocks; stringing of _large_ beads; weaving with _wide_ strips of colored paper simple designs that a mother could invent with the material at hand or could learn from any kindergarten manual.
column3: The laying in simple designs, by watchful imitation of the mother, of colored sticks, colored squares, etc; the building with colored blocks; stringing of underscore large underscore beads; weaving with underscore wide underscore strips of colored paper simple designs that a mother could invent with the material at hand or could learn from any kindergarten manual.

column2: The point that must be firmly, but _pleasantly_, insisted upon in these exercises is careful and obedient following by the child of the exact order of movement and manner of placing adopted by the mother teacher.
column3: The point that must be firmly, but underscore pleasantly underscore, insisted upon in these exercises is careful and obedient following by the child of the exact order of movement and manner of placing adopted by the mother teacher.

column2: The entire value of these exercises for the purpose she wishes to accomplish depends upon _accurate observation_ by the child and _implicit obedience_.
column3: The entire value of these exercises for the purpose she wishes to accomplish depends upon underscore accurate observation underscore by the child and underscore implicit obedience underscore.

column2: The material outfit prepared and sold by the American exploiters of the Montessori method is admirably adapted to the development of the budding faculties of the child, and the mother who is trying to do all in her power to prepare her little one to benefit to the greatest possible extent from the professional instruction that must come later, will make no mistake in supplying herself with the set of materials, and making herself intelligent on their use by the child.
column3: The material outfit prepared and sold by the American exploiters of the Montessori method is admirably adapted to the development of the budding faculties of the child, and the mother who is trying to do all in her power to prepare her little one to benefit to the greatest possible extent from the professional instruction that must come later, will make no mistake in supplying herself with the set of materials, and making herself intelligent on their use by the child.

column2: VI
column3: VI

column2: DEVELOPING THE LUNGS
column3: DEVELOPING THE LUNGS

column2: The tendency of the deaf child is to grow up with less development of lungs and of the imagination than hearing children.
column3: The tendency of the deaf child is to grow up with less development of lungs and of the imagination than hearing children.

column2: In order to overcome this tendency the child must be encouraged and _taught_ to play games and use toys that will exercise the lungs and develop the power of imaginative thought.
column3: In order to overcome this tendency the child must be encouraged and underscore taught underscore to play games and use toys that will exercise the lungs and develop the power of imaginative thought.

column2: In order to expand and strengthen the lungs through the child's play, supply him with the brightly colored paper wind-mills that he can set whirling by blowing lustily; also the rubber balloon toys, even though the torturing squeak of the toys is only heard by those in the vicinity and not by himself.
column3: In order to expand and strengthen the lungs through the child's play, supply him with the brightly colored paper wind mills that he can set whirling by blowing lustily; also the rubber balloon toys, even though the torturing squeak of the toys is only heard by those in the vicinity and not by himself.

column2: An especially good exercise for the gentle and long-continued control of breath results from the toy blow pipes with conical wire bowls by means of which light, celluloid balls of bright colors are kept suspended in the air, dancing on the column of breath blown softly through the tube.
column3: An especially good exercise for the gentle and long continued control of breath results from the toy blow pipes with conical wire bowls by means of which light, celluloid balls of bright colors are kept suspended in the air, dancing on the column of breath blown softly through the tube.

column2: The more steadily the child blows, the more mysteriously the ball remains at a fixed point, whirling rapidly but without any apparent support.
column3: The more steadily the child blows, the more mysteriously the ball remains at a fixed point, whirling rapidly but without any apparent support.

column2: Blowing soap bubbles, especially trying to blow big ones, is very useful as well as interesting.
column3: Blowing soap bubbles, especially trying to blow big ones, is very useful as well as interesting.

column2: For physical development in which the lungs come in for their share and the sense of mechanical rhythm is fostered, an excellent exercise is marching in step to the stroke of the drum, proud in Boy Scout uniform. Dancing is a very desirable accomplishment for the deaf child.
column3: For physical development in which the lungs come in for their share and the sense of mechanical rhythm is fostered, an excellent exercise is marching in step to the stroke of the drum, proud in Boy Scout uniform. Dancing is a very desirable accomplishment for the deaf child.

column2: Tops and tenpins cultivate dexterity, as do playing ball and rolling hoop.
column3: Tops and tenpins cultivate dexterity, as do playing ball and rolling hoop.

column2: VII
column3: seven

column2: THE CULTIVATION OF CREATIVE IMAGINATION
column3: THE CULTIVATION OF CREATIVE IMAGINATION

column2: This can be greatly helped by early use on the part of the child of colored modeling wax to reproduce objects and animals, and to construct models of imaginary houses, yards, trees, etc.
column3: This can be greatly helped by early use on the part of the child of colored modeling wax to reproduce objects and animals, and to construct models of imaginary houses, yards, trees, etc

column2: A sand pile, or a large, shallow sand box, perhaps five feet square, with sides six inches high, and completely lined with enamel cloth to make it watertight, is a wonderful implement for constructive play on the part of the child. Whole villages of farms, fields, and forests, ponds and brooks, roads and railroads, can be made here in miniature.
column3: A sand pile, or a large, shallow sand box, perhaps five feet square, with sides six inches high, and completely lined with enamel cloth to make it watertight, is a wonderful implement for constructive play on the part of the child. Whole villages of farms, fields, and forests, ponds and brooks, roads and railroads, can be made here in miniature.

column2: Building blocks of wood or stone; the metal construction toy called "Mechano"; dolls, doll houses, furniture, and equipment, are valuable, but they should be simple, inexpensive and not fragile.
column3: Building blocks of wood or stone; the metal construction toy called "Mechano"; dolls, doll houses, furniture, and equipment, are valuable, but they should be simple, inexpensive and not fragile.

column2: Cut-up picture puzzles, painting books, tracing slates with large and simple designs cultivate observation and ingenuity.
column3: Cut up picture puzzles, painting books, tracing slates with large and simple designs cultivate observation and ingenuity.

column2: Kaleidoscopes and stereoscopes are excellent, but moving pictures are so trying upon the eyes, and the air of the theaters is so bad, that a deaf child whose eyes are his only salvation, and whose health is doubly important, should not even know of their existence till he is seven or eight years old.
column3: Kaleidoscopes and stereoscopes are excellent, but moving pictures are so trying upon the eyes, and the air of the theaters is so bad, that a deaf child whose eyes are his only salvation, and whose health is doubly important, should not even know of their existence till he is seven or eight years old.
